occurrences.line_text: Eft through the thicke they heard one rudely rush;
Through the dull billowes thicke as troubled mire,
Through that thicke couert he him led, and found
With a thicke Arber goodly ouer dight,
And loaden all with fruit as thicke as it might bee.
For in his shield, as thicke as stormie showre,
And some like vgly Vrchins thicke and short:
Their fluttring arrowes, thicke as flakes of snow,
Through thicke and thin, both ouer banke and bush
Like to thicke cloudes, that threat a stormy showre,
Thicke forest, was bescratcht, & both his feet nigh lame.
Through the thicke woods, wherein he would haue hid
There in await, with thicke woods ouer growne,
Through thicke and thin her to pursew apace,
As thicke as hayle forth poured from the skie:
So thicke they fell, and forcibly were sent,
Of people, thronging thicke her to behold,
Heaping huge strokes, as thicke as showre of hayle,
And cluster thicke vnto his leasings vaine,
And arrowes haild so thicke, that they could not abide.
As thicke as doth the seede after the sowers hand;
The tyrant thundred his thicke blowes so fast,
Through thicke and thin, vnfit for any Dame.
Through the thicke clouds, in which they steeped lay
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
The couert was so thicke, that did no passage shew.
For the thicke shrubs, which did them alwaies shade
Amid the thickest woods. The Champion stout
It fortuned out of the thickest wood
All suddenly out of the thickest brush,
Till that she rushing through the thickest preasse,
And in the thickest couert of that shade,
Now when amid the thickest woods they were,
Into the thickest of that knightly preasse
Then rushed forth out of the thickest rout
One rushing forth out of the thickest weed,
And through the thickest makes her nighest waies;
And thrusting fierce into the thickest preace,
And through the thickest like a Lyon flew,
Forth from the thickest preasse of people came,
By whom they passing, through the thickest preasse,
And running streight into the thickest wood,
With that he thrusts into the thickest throng,
Their thickest troups, & round about him scattreth wide.
Anone one sent out of the thicket neare
The silly man that in the thicket lay
Through many couert groues, and thickets close,
Ne feeles the thorns and thickets pricke her tender toes.
He was to weete a stout and sturdie thiefe,
Then hopelesse hartlesse, gan the cunning thiefe
And fowly said, By Mahoune, cursed thiefe,
He ment the thiefe there deadly to haue smit:
For which he chalenged the thiefe to fight.
Him hardly forward drew, whereas the thiefe
Forth creeping on his caitiue hands and thies,
That through his thigh the mortall steele did gryde:
In his left thigh, and deepely did it thrill:
She his hurt thigh to him recur'd againe,
Her siluer buskins from her nimble thigh,
That through the mayles into his thigh it entred,
Vppon her thigh her Cemitare was tide,
That glauncing downe his thigh, the purple bloud forth drew.
But without sword vpon his thigh to sit:
Whose feeble thighes, vnhable to vphold
That his frayle thighes nigh wearie and fordonne
Her goodly thighes, whose glorie did appeare
Arayd in habit blacke, and amis thin,
He had beene pouldred all, as thin as flowre:
His bare thin cheekes for want of better bits,
Through her thin weed their places only signifide.
Infinite shapes of things dispersed thin;
All in a canuas thin he was bedight,
Yet was the fence thereof but weake and thin;
All in a vele of silke and siluer thin,
Through thicke and thin, both ouer banke and bush
Where she may find the substaunce thin and light,
Through thick and thin, through mountaines & through plains,
A litle smoke, whose vapour thin and light,
Through thicke and thin her to pursew apace,
To see their thrids so thin, as spiders frame,
He with his yron flale did thresh so thin,
Through thicke and thin, vnfit for any Dame.
Through thick and thin, through mountains & through plains,
Lay forth out of thine euerlasting scryne
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
Or thine the fault, or mine the error is,
The false Duessa, Thine the shield, and I, and all.
To loue another. Lo then for thine ayd
But vanquisht thine eternall bondslaue make,
Defend thine honour, and thy foes confound:
Thine, O then, said the gentle Redcrosse knight,
With thine owne bloud to price his bloud, here shed in sight.
And guiltie be of thine impietie?
Shalt be a Saint, and thine owne nations frend
And thine owne realmes in lond of Faery,
Emongst thine equall peres, where happie blis
Or bide the chaunce at thine owne ieoperdie.
Thereby thine armes seeme stro[n]g, but manhood fraile;
So hast thou oft with guile thine honour blent;
Of PhÃ¦dria, thine owne fellow seruaunt;
How they themselues doe thine ensample make,
That here in desert hast thine habitaunce,
Ne thine be kingdomes, ne the scepters thine;
Ne thine be kingdomes, ne the scepters thine;
Certes (said he) I n'ill thine offred grace,
That all thine idle offers I refuse.
And all the day, when as thine equall peares,
But thine my Deare (welfare thy heart my deare)
But better fortune thine, and better howre,
But standing high aloft, low lay thine eare,
Yet shall a third both these, and thine subdew;
Is this thine high aduauncement, ï¿½ is this
To send thine Angell from her bowre of blis,
And in thine ashes buried low dost lie,
So long vnwreaked of thine enimy?
If she were thine, and thou as now am I?
Why doth mine hand from thine auenge abstaine,
Of thine owne spirit, which doth in me suruiue,
And chaung'd at pleasure for those impes of thine.
Not for thine owne, but for thy sisters sake,
Vnweeting of thine owne like haplesse plight:
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
Not so thou Squire, (he sayd) but thine I deeme
But thine owne people do thy mercy prayse much more.
But euen that which thou sauedst, thine still to remaine?
And for thine owne defence on foote alight,
Vnfit he was for any worldy thing,
To dare the thing, which daily yet I rew,
Why fearest thou, that canst not hope for thing,
The thing, that might not be, and yet was donne?
And did with store of euery thing abound,
A thing without the compas of my wit:
Or other griesly thing, that him agast.
Is not his deed, what euer thing is donne,
Each goodly thing is hardest to begin,
Strange thing it is an errant knight to see
And mortall life gan loath, as thing forlore,
Did spend their dayes in doing godly thing:
Panthea, seemd the brightest thing, that was:
What euer thing does touch his rauenous pawes,
To weet, what dreadfull thing was there in hand;
Weake she makes stro[n]g & stro[n]g thing does increace,
That earthly thing may not my courage braue
Ne euer thing could cause vs disagree:
Ne euer thing, that she could thinke or see,
Was ouercome of thing, that did him please;
That of no wordly thing he care did take;
That euery weightie thing they did vpbeare,
So euill thing to seeke vnto their ayd,
But thing refused, do not afterward accuse.
Thing offred, till I know it well be got,
Or lips he layd on thing, that likt him best,
The thing, that thou didst craue so earnestly,
But of thing like to that ï¿½/-gyptian slime,
Soone it must turne to earth; no earthly thing is sure.
So long as any thing it in the caudron got.
That is each thing, by which the eyes may fault:
So greatest and most glorious thing on ground
Ah see, who so faire thing doest faine to see,
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
For hardy thing it is, to weene by might,
With hope of thing, that may allegge his smart;
What euer thing was in the world contaynd,
Of much more vncouth thing I was affrayd;
First rooting tooke; but what thing it mote bee,
And sheweth each thing, as it is indeed:
Of euery thing consumes, and calcineth by art.
Who in her sleepe (a wondrous thing to say)
T'adore thing so diuine as beauty, were but right.
These twinnes, men say, (a thing far passing thought)
Who thereby deeming sure the thing as donne,
The thing it selfe. In hand she boldly tooke
That thing of course he counted, loue to entertaine.
Perdy not so; (said she) for shamefull thing
Straunge thing it seem'd, that none was to possesse
No word they spake, nor earthly thing they felt,
For thy, they ought not thing vnknowne reproue,
She sought to saue, as thing reseru'd from stealth;
For thing vnlawfull, that was not his owne:
That neuer thoght one thing, but doubly stil was guided.
Fond knight (sayd she) the thing that with this eye
Therewith, as thing deuiz'd her to defame.
Ne thenceforth feare the thing that hethertoo
For bootlesse thing it was to think such blowes to beare.
And vnto euery thing did aunswere mum:
Ne euer thing so well was doen aliue,
That lou'd me deare, as dearest thing aliue.
And folly seem'd to leaue the thing vndonne,
That of no worldly thing he tooke delight;
And doe what euer thing he did intend.
For any thing wold slacke, but still vppon him hong.
What thing so many nations met, did there desire.
In euery thing, thou oughtest first to know,
What euer thing is done, by him is donne,
vThat doest not know the least thing of them all?
To see the thing, that seem'd so excellent,
As thing at randon left, to whom he list.
Ne doth she giue them other thing to eat,
But bread and water, or like feeble thing,
Snatching at euery thing, doth wreake her wrath
Whether this heauenly thing, whereof I treat,
For when she wanteth other thing to eat,
And turne to ill the thing, that well was ment.
For euerie thing, to which one is inclin'd,
For thing of weight, or worke of greater care,
And him to beare, she thought it thing too base.
And shrieked out, a thing vncomely for a knight.
O What an easie thing is to descry
Mote easie be supprest with little thing:
And falleth downe to ground like senselesse thing,
To doe some thing, that seemed to him best,
For bootelesse thing him seemed, to abide
Nor that thing worst, which men do most refuse;
Or other daintie thing for her addrest,
What euer thing he did her to aggrate,
Sith otherwise he could not mend thing past;
Nor euer thought thing so vnworthily:
Which of all earthly things he most did craue;
With holy father sits not with such things to mell.
His holy things each morne and euentyde:
Rest is their feast, and all things at their will;
Whiles none the holy things in safety kept;
And now he to her brought part of his stolen things.
And all things else, the which his art did teach:
And prowdly threw to ground, as things of naught;
The sacred things, and holy heasts foretaught.
Be iudge ye heauens, that all things right esteeme,
And he that high does sit, and all things see
The things, that grieuous were to do, or beare,
Thus as they gan of sundry things deuise,
Wherein darke things were writ, hard to be vnderstood.
So darke are earthly things compard to things diuine.
So darke are earthly things compard to things diuine.
Saue in that soile, where all good things did grow,
And later times things more vnknowne shall show.
Which vnto things of valorous pretence
Sheilds, steeds, and armes, & all things for thee meet
The hatefull messengers of heauy things,
The cloudes, as things affrayd, before him flye;
The first of them could things to come foresee:
The next could of things present best aduize;
The third things past could keepe in memoree,
Infinite shapes of things dispersed thin;
And things foregone through many ages held,
As all things else, the which this world doth weld,
And oft when things were lost, or laid amis,
That all things one, and one as nothing was,
By which the mightiest things efforced bin:
Who wondrous things concerning our welfare,
As diuerse wits to diuers things apply;
Of sundry things faire purpose gan to find,
Ay doing things, that to his fame redound,
Of dreadfull things the same was put to flight,
Things oft impossible (quoth she) seeme, ere begonne.
And hostes of men of meanest things could frame,
For so must all things excellent begin,
And bad her all things put in readinesse anon.
But all things did conueniently puruay:
Of diuerse things discourses to dilate,
Exceeding riches and all pretious things,
That doest all things deface, ne lettest see
Of all things liuing, through impression
She promist kisses sweet, and sweeter things
Of all things, that are borne to liue and die,
All things, as they created were, doe grow,
All things from thence doe their first being fetch,
Does mow the flowring herbes and goodly things,
To see so faire things mard, and spoyled quight:
All things decay in time, and to their end do draw.
In balefull night, where all things are forgot;
The knights were willing all things to excuse,
And seru'd of all things that mote needfull bee;
Fruitfull of all things fit for liuing foode,
Two things he feared, but the third was death;
Thus whilest all things in troublous vprore were,
That cruell element, which all things feare,
Full dreadfull things out of that balefull booke
And call to count the things that then were donne,
Full many things so doubtfull to be wayd,
That seem'd full hard t'accord two things so far in dout.
Altars defyl'd, and holy things defast,
And sought to bring all things vnto decay;
How she might ouerthrow the things that Concord wrought.
All things not rooted well, will soone be rotten.
And all things did deuise, and all things dooe,
And all things did deuise, and all things dooe,
Of secret things, and all the powres of nature,
And sayd, Fond dame that deem'st of things diuine
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
She seem'd to passe: so forged things do fairest shew.
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
Till I thereto had all things ready dight.
From all forbidden things his liking to withdraw.
Much dearer be the things, which come through hard distresse.
So all things else, that nourish vitall blood,
Which on her waited, things amisse to mend,
As all things else in time are chaunged quight.
And all things freely grew out of the ground:
And all things secrete wisely could bewray,
And all things would reduce vnto equality.
And all things to an equall to restore,
Seest not, how badly all things present bee,
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
Sith thou misdeem'st so much of things in sight?
Sith of things subiect to thy daily vew
That he of little things made reckoning light,
So feeble skill of perfect things the vulgar has.
For vaine it is to deeme of things aright,
But tract of time, that all things doth decay,
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
And all things quieted, the Elfin Knight
And gaue them gifts and things of deare delight.
That this is things compacte betwixt you two,
Of things abrode, as next to hand did light,
And many things demaund, to which she answer'd light.
And talk't of pleasant things, the night away to weare.
To shew that she had powre in things diuine;
About their holy things for morrow Mas:
To shew that clemence oft in things amis,
(As often falles) of sundry things did commen.
Hymnes to high God, and carols heauenly things,
Of all things to dissemble fouly may befall.
He all things did puruay, which for them needfull weare.
Which see not perfet things but in a glas:
So tickle is the state of earthly things,
And moued speach to him of things of course,
That they mote treat of things abrode at leasure;
Both speare and shield, as things that needlesse were,
About the sad Serena things to dight,
So hauing all things well about her dight,
Was wont his howres and holy things to bed;
From things, that stirre vp fraile affection;
There whilest he thus was setling things aboue,
Thus hauing all things well in peace ordayned,
Hauing his armes and warlike things vndight,
I put repentaunce for things past and gon.
Tho when as all things readie were aright,
Of sundry things, as fell, to worke delay;
And all things therein meane, yet better so
Had euer learn'd to loue the lowly things,
Keeping all noysome things away from it,
But since things passed none may now restore,
A doubtfull sense of things, not so well seene, as felt.
And seeking all things meete for remedy.
Of sundrie things he purpose gan to faine;
To cherish her with all things choice and rare;
Tho further asking her of sundry things,
And spake licentious words, and hatefull things
Or think, that ought those puissant hands may marre:
For bootlesse thing it was to think such blowes to beare.
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
To thinke how she through guilefull handeling,
To thinke that knighthood I so much should shame,
Yet did she thinke her pearelesse wroth to pas
And greeu'd, to thinke how foe did him destroy,
To thinke of wight so faire, but gazing stood,
Soone as I thinke vpon my bitter bale:
So thought I eke of him, and thinke I thought aright.
It booted nought, to thinke, such thunderbolts to beare.
How dare I thinke such glory to attaine?
To thinke of those her captiue Parents deare,
Hart cannot thinke, what outrage, and what cryes,
It booted nought to thinke, to robbe him of his pray.
Who then would thinke, that by his subtile trains
To thinke without desert of gentle deed,
Not so, Ã´ Guyon, neuer thinke that so
Ne euer thing, that she could thinke or see,
To thinke, such hideous puissaunce on foot to beare.
But would they thinke, with how small allowaunce
And stretching forth his hand, did often thinke
To thinke, how supper did them long awaite.
It booted not to thinke that throw to beare,
Ne wist he, what to thinke of that same sight,
And thinke of that faire visage, written in her hart.
To thinke, how causelesse of her owne accord
So made him thinke him selfe in heauen, that was in hell.
Beholding it from far, do thinke it threates the skye.
With burden of great treasure, I thinke best
Must not here thinke to liue: for life is wretchednesse.
That dare fro me thinke Florimell to take.
Once thinke to match three such on equall cost,
All which who so dare thinke for to enchace,
But she her selfe did thinke it doen for spight,
And euermore, when he to sleepe did thinke,
And in his madnesse thinke with hands impure
Or both of them did thinke, obedience
Ne thinke th'affection of her hart to draw
That euen to thinke thereof, it inly pitties mee.
Or ought more hard, then thinke to reckon right.
Then gan he thinke, perforce with sword and targe
Most did she thinke, but most she thought amis,
Least did she thinke, that which he most concealed,
Ne wist he what to thinke, or to deuise,
But vaine it was to thinke from him to flie.
To thinke with how great vaunt of brauerie
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
To thinke of him so ill: yet could she not forbeare.
To thinke of your nights want, that should yee waking keepe.
There they did thinke them selues on her to wreake:
To thinke to follow him, that was so swift and light.
Who then can thinke their hedlong ruine to recure.
Such loathly matter were small lust to speake, or thinke.
The wisest sight, to thinke gold that is bras.
From which to thinke to saue himselfe, it booted not.
For that displeasure; and thinke what reliefe
To thinke of this ill state, in which she stood,
Fearelesse, who ought did thinke, or ought did say,
Gaping full wyde, did thinke without remorse
And makes exceeding mone, when he does thinke
She made him thinke it surely was his owne,
Him booted not to thinke them to pursew,
Asham'd to thinke, how he that enterprize,
And by my ruines thinkes to make them great:
His owne faire Dryope now he thinkes not faire,
So th'euill thinkes by watching to preuent;
Who euer thinkes through confidence of might,
Who thinkes from me his sorrow all doth rize.
And thinking of those braunches greene to frame
Thinking to ouerthrow and downe him tred:
So thinking for to make her stubborne courage quaile.
Thinking to worke on her his vtmost wracke,
Thinking to hide the depth by troubling of the flood.
As was her wont, thinking to let her weet
Full farre was I from thinking such a pranke;
Thinking to haue her griefe by death bereaued.
Thinking at once both head and helmet to haue raced.
He ran still on, thinking to follow fast
But thinking best by counterfet disguise
Thinking to pay him with that one for all:
Thinking the vtmost of their force to trie,
With thinking to what case her name should now be brought.
Thinking by speed to ouertake his flight;
Thinking to take them from that hylding hound:
Through the thick prease, there thinking him to hyde.
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
So shakes off shame, ne thinks how erst she did her hide.
Such one was Lecherie, the third of all this traine.
The third had of their wardrobe custodie,
The third him ouerthrowes, and gayns
I meant to purge both with a third mischiefe,
From the third brunt of this my fatall brond:
This fround, that faund, the third for shame did blush,
The third things past could keepe in memoree,
Likewise that same third Fort, that is the Smell
Of that third troupe was cruelly assayd:
Tho when appeared the third Morrow bright,
But the third time shall faire accordaunce make:
But the third time shall rew his foolhardise:
Yet shall a third both these, and thine subdew;
His mother swowned thrise, and the third time
Where the third brother him did sore assay,
The third a Damzell was of low degree,
But a third kingdome yet is to arise,
Two things he feared, but the third was death;
Vnto the third, that his may so be trebly wext.
The third dayes prize vnto that straunger Knight,
The third, the goodly Barow, which doth hoord
The third was Brunell, famous in his dayes;
The third day came, that should due tryall lend
And the third time out of an hidden shade,
The third nor strong nor wise, but spightfullest Defetto.
Will die for thirst, and water doth refuse?
For thirst of single kingdome him he kild.
But Ã´ the greedy thirst of royall crowne,
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
And drinke of euery brooke, when thirst my throte doth boyle.
And quite dismembred hath: the thirstie land
He sought all round about, his thirstie blade
There thirstie Tantalus hong by the chin;
Offred him drinke, to quench his thirstie heat,
In the coole soile, after long thirstinesse,
Nigh thirtie minutes to the Southerne lake;
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
Whom to auenge, she had this Knight from far co[m]peld.
And this faire couple eke to shroud the[m]selues were fain.
Yea but (quoth she) the perill of this place
This is the wandring wood, this Errours den,
This is the wandring wood, this Errours den,
The fearefull Dwarfe:) this is no place for liuing men.
Wherein ye haue great glory wonne this day,
That wasteth all this countrey farre and neare.
For this same night. The knight was well content:
Who all this while with charmes and hidden artes,
In this great passion of vnwonted lust,
By this the Northerne wagoner had set
At last it chaunced this proud Sarazin
In this sad plight, friendlesse, vnfortunate,
He in great passion all this while did dwell,
But this good knight soone as he them can spie,
My tender sides in this rough rynd embard,
And to this wretched Lady, my deare loue,
To loue this gentle Lady, whom ye see,
The wicked witch now seeing all this while
Then brought she me into this desert waste,
Are you in this misformed house to dwell?
We may not chaunge (quoth he) this euil plight,
